verses.text: Then David fled from Naioth in Ramah and came to Jonathan. He said, 'What have I done? What is my guilt, and what is my sin before your father, that he seeks my life?'
verses.comment: David questions Jonathan about Saul's hostility.

verses.text: He said to him, 'Far from it! You shall not die. See, my father does nothing either great or small without telling me. Why would my father hide this from me? It isn't so.'
verses.comment: Jonathan assures David he would know if Saul planned to kill him.

verses.text: But David took an oath again and said, 'Your father knows well that I have found favor in your eyes, and he thinks, “Do not let Jonathan know this, or he will be grieved.” But truly, as the LORD lives and as your soul lives, there is but a step between me and death.'
verses.comment: "As the LORD lives" is a traditional Hebrew oath phrase.

verses.text: Then Jonathan said to David, 'Whatever you want, I will do for you.'
And David said to Jonathan, 'Look, tomorrow is the new moon, and I am to sit at table with the king. But let me go, that I may hide myself in the field until the third day at evening.'
verses.comment: "New moon" refers to the monthly festival.

verses.text: If your father misses me at all, then say, “David earnestly asked leave of me to run to Bethlehem his city, because there is a yearly sacrifice there for all the clan.”
verses.comment: David's request is a plausible excuse to explain his absence.

verses.text: 'If he says, “Good!” it will be well with your servant. But if he is angry, then know that harm is determined by him.'

'Therefore deal kindly with your servant, for you have brought your servant into a covenant of the LORD with you. But if there is guilt in me, kill me yourself, for why should you bring me to your father?'
Jonathan said, 'Far be it from you! If I knew that harm was determined by my father to come upon you, would I not tell you?'
Then David said to Jonathan, 'Who will tell me if your father answers you harshly?'
Jonathan said to David, 'Come, let us go out into the field.' So they both went out into the field.

And Jonathan said to David, 'The LORD, the God of Israel, be witness! When I have tested my father sometime tomorrow or the third day, if he is well disposed toward David, shall I not then send and disclose it to you?'
verses.comment: "The LORD…be witness" is a Hebrew oath formula.

verses.text: 'But if it pleases my father to do you harm, the LORD do so to Jonathan and more also, if I do not disclose it to you and send you away, that you may go in safety. May the LORD be with you as he has been with my father.'
'If I am still alive, show me the faithful love of the LORD, that I may not die.'
verses.comment: Jonathan foresees the risk to himself.

verses.text: 'And do not cut off your steadfast love from my house forever, not even when the LORD cuts off every one of the enemies of David from the face of the earth.'
So Jonathan made a covenant with the house of David, saying, 'May the LORD take vengeance on David’s enemies.'
And Jonathan made David swear again by his love for him, for he loved him as he loved his own soul.
Then Jonathan said to him, 'Tomorrow is the new moon, and you will be missed because your seat will be empty.'
'On the third day, go down quickly to the place where you hid yourself when this trouble began, and wait beside the stone heap.'
verses.comment: 'The stone heap' is literal—some Hebrew manuscripts have 'Ezel.'

verses.text: 'And I will shoot three arrows to the side of it, as though I shot at a mark.'

'And look, I will send the boy, saying, “Go, find the arrows.” If I say to the boy, “Look, the arrows are on this side of you, take them,” then come, for as the LORD lives, it is safe for you and there is no danger.'
'But if I say to the youth, “Look, the arrows are beyond you,” then go, for the LORD has sent you away.'
'And as for the matter about which you and I have spoken, behold, the LORD is between you and me forever.'
So David hid himself in the field. And when the new moon came, the king sat down to eat food.
The king sat on his seat, as at other times, on the seat by the wall. Jonathan sat opposite, and Abner sat by Saul's side, but David’s place was empty.
Yet Saul did not say anything that day, for he thought, 'Something has happened to him. He is not clean; surely he is not clean.'
But on the second day, the day after the new moon, David's place was still empty. And Saul said to Jonathan his son, 'Why has the son of Jesse not come to the meal, either yesterday or today?'
verses.comment: Saul refers to David as 'the son of Jesse.'

verses.text: Jonathan answered Saul, 'David earnestly asked leave of me to go to Bethlehem.'

'He said, “Let me go, for our clan holds a sacrifice in the city, and my brother has commanded me to be there. So now, if I have found favor in your eyes, let me go away and see my brothers.” For this reason he has not come to the king’s table.'

Then Saul’s anger was kindled against Jonathan, and he said to him, 'You son of a perverse, rebellious woman! Do I not know that you have chosen the son of Jesse to your own shame and to the shame of your mother’s nakedness?'
verses.comment: Saul uses insulting language to rebuke Jonathan.

verses.text: 'For as long as the son of Jesse lives on the earth, neither you nor your kingdom will be established. Therefore send and bring him to me, for he shall surely die.'
Then Jonathan answered Saul his father, 'Why should he be put to death? What has he done?'
But Saul hurled his spear at him to strike him. So Jonathan knew that his father was determined to put David to death.
verses.comment: Saul throws a spear at his own son.

verses.text: And Jonathan rose from the table in fierce anger and ate no food the second day of the month, for he was grieved for David, because his father had treated him shamefully.
In the morning Jonathan went out into the field to the appointment with David, and a little boy was with him.
And he said to his boy, 'Run and find the arrows that I shoot.' As the boy ran, he shot an arrow beyond him.
When the boy came to the place of the arrow that Jonathan had shot, Jonathan called after the boy and said, 'Is not the arrow beyond you?'
And Jonathan called after the boy, 'Hurry! Be quick, do not stay!' So Jonathan’s boy gathered up the arrows and came back to his master.
But the boy knew nothing; only Jonathan and David knew the matter.
And Jonathan gave his weapons to his boy and said to him, 'Go and carry them to the city.'

As soon as the boy had gone, David rose from beside the stone heap and fell on his face to the ground and bowed three times. And they kissed one another and wept with one another, David weeping the most.
verses.comment: Gesture of greeting in ancient times; reflects depth of friendship, not romantic.

verses.text: Then Jonathan said to David, 'Go in peace, because we have both sworn in the name of the LORD, saying, “The LORD shall be between me and you, and between my descendants and your descendants, forever.”' And he rose and departed, and Jonathan went into the city.
verses.comment: Finalizes the covenant between David and Jonathan and their descendants.
